metadata.title: Convert Bar to PSI – Pressure Converter
metadata.description: Convert pressure from bar to pounds per square inch (PSI) using the exact conversion factor, essential for comparing industrial pressure specifications, automotive tire ratings, and hydraulic system documentation across metric and imperial standards.

introduction: This converter transforms pressures from bar (metric pressure unit) to PSI (pounds per square inch), the imperial pressure unit. It is designed for engineers, technicians, and equipment operators who need to compare pressure specifications across metric-using and imperial-using regions.

The bar is commonly used in Europe, Asia, and industrial applications worldwide, while PSI remains the standard in the United States, Canada, and some Commonwealth countries. A single pressure value can appear dramatically different when expressed in these two units—for instance, 1 bar is roughly 14.5 PSI—making conversions essential when selecting equipment, setting gauges, or troubleshooting pressure systems.

This converter applies the exact, legally standardized relationship between bar and PSI, so results are reliable for pressure gauge calibration, equipment specification comparison, safety system design, and compliance documentation.
methodology: The bar is defined in metric terms: 1 bar = 100,000 pascals (Pa), where the pascal is the SI unit of pressure. The PSI is defined in imperial terms: 1 PSI = 1 pound-force per square inch. The exact relationship between these is established through the standard conversion between pounds-force and newtons: 1 pound-force = 4.448222 newtons (exactly). Combined with inch-to-meter conversion (1 inch = 0.0254 meters, exactly), the conversion factor is: 1 bar = 14.50377 PSI.

To convert a pressure from bar to PSI, you multiply the value in bar by 14.50377. For example, 1 bar = 14.50377 PSI, 5 bar = 72.51885 PSI, and 10 bar = 145.0377 PSI. This factor is documented in NIST conversion tables and is the standard used by equipment manufacturers, pressure gauge calibrators, and engineering references worldwide.

The converter applies full-precision floating-point multiplication internally. Results are displayed rounded to practical precision (typically two to four decimal places), but the underlying calculation maintains maximum precision, ensuring accuracy suitable for equipment selection, pressure system design, and safety-critical applications.

Because the conversion factor is exact and internationally standardized, this converter produces results that match official pressure conversion tables, equipment specification sheets, and calibration references. The factor has been in use consistently since bar was internationally adopted as a practical unit for pressure measurement.

In critical applications such as hydraulic systems, compressed gas storage, or pressure vessel design, the numerical conversion should be combined with proper pressure gauge calibration, pressure relief valve settings, and adherence to applicable codes and standards (such as ASME boiler and pressure vessel codes).
examples: Example 1 – Automotive tire pressure: A typical car tire specification is 2.2 bar. Converting to PSI: 2.2 × 14.50377 ≈ 31.91 PSI, which matches common tire pressure recommendations in the United States.
Example 2 – Industrial hydraulic systems: A hydraulic system rated at 210 bar converts to approximately 3,045.79 PSI. This is a typical high-pressure hydraulic application in industrial machinery.
Example 3 – Compressed air lines: A standard compressed air supply of 6 bar converts to approximately 87.02 PSI, typical for pneumatic tool and production line applications.

Example 4 – Reference pressure: Standard atmospheric pressure is 1.01325 bar, which converts to approximately 14.696 PSI. This is the 'sea level standard' used in barometer readings and pressure baseline calculations worldwide.

faqs.question: What is the exact conversion from bar to PSI?
faqs.answer: By international definition, 1 bar = 14.50377 PSI (exactly). To convert any pressure in bar to PSI, multiply by 14.50377. This factor is documented in NIST conversion standards and is used consistently by pressure gauge manufacturers and engineering references.

faqs.question: Why is the conversion factor exactly 14.50377?
faqs.answer: The bar is defined as 100,000 pascals (SI unit). The PSI is defined as 1 pound-force per square inch. The exact relationship is derived from the standardized conversions: 1 lbf = 4.448222 N (exactly) and 1 inch = 0.0254 meters (exactly). These combine to give 1 bar = 14.50377 PSI.

faqs.question: What pressure units are most common globally?
faqs.answer: The bar is widely used in Europe, Asia, and many industrial applications. The PSI is standard in the United States, Canada, and some Commonwealth countries. The pascal (Pa) and kilopascal (kPa) are SI base units used in scientific work. Modern pressure gauges often display multiple scales to accommodate different regional standards.

faqs.question: Is this converter suitable for pressure gauge calibration?
faqs.answer: Yes. The conversion factor 14.50377 is the standard used by pressure gauge calibrators and metrology labs. However, for critical calibration work, physical comparison with certified reference gauges or traceable deadweight standards is recommended, as gauge accuracy depends on proper mechanical function, not just unit conversion.

faqs.question: How many decimal places should I use in pressure conversions?
faqs.answer: For most applications (tire pressure, general industrial), one to two decimal places are sufficient. For engineering design or system setup, maintain three to four significant figures (e.g., 210 bar = 3,045.8 PSI). For calibration or regulatory documentation, follow the procedure specified in your quality manual or standards document.

faqs.question: What is the difference between bar and millibar?
faqs.answer: 1 bar = 1,000 millibars (mbar). The millibar is commonly used in meteorology for barometer and weather pressure readings. For example, standard atmospheric pressure is 1,013.25 mbar or 1.01325 bar. This converter handles bar; for millibar conversions, divide or multiply by 1,000 as needed.

faqs.question: Can I use this converter for absolute pressure and gauge pressure?
faqs.answer: Yes. The conversion factor applies equally to absolute pressure (measured from a perfect vacuum) and gauge pressure (measured from atmospheric pressure). However, you must ensure your input value is consistently labeled as absolute or gauge, since the conversion does not change the reference point—only the units.

faqs.question: How do modern pressure systems display both bar and PSI?
faqs.answer: Many modern pressure gauges, sensor readouts, and equipment displays show both scales simultaneously using dual-scale faces or digital readouts that toggle between units. They use this exact conversion factor (14.50377) to ensure that readings are numerically synchronized, so 1 bar and 14.50377 PSI represent the same pressure.

glossary.definition: A metric unit of pressure equal to 100,000 pascals (Pa). Widely used in Europe, Asia, and industrial applications. One bar is slightly less than standard atmospheric pressure (1.01325 bar = 1 atm).

An imperial unit of pressure equal to the force of one pound exerted over an area of one square inch. Standard in the United States and some Commonwealth countries. Often written as 'psia' (absolute) or 'psig' (gauge).
The SI base unit of pressure, equal to one newton per square meter. One bar equals 100,000 pascals. The pascal is used in scientific and technical documentation worldwide.
Pressure measured from a perfect vacuum (zero reference). Both bar and PSI can be used for absolute pressure values; the conversion factor is the same.

Pressure measured relative to atmospheric pressure. A pressure gauge reading 0 at sea level is actually at 1 atm of absolute pressure. Conversion between bar and PSI applies to gauge pressure the same way as absolute pressure.
